verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “See, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet.”
verses.comment: ‘Like God’ (Heb. ‘Elohim’): Moses is empowered to speak and act with the authority of God before Pharaoh.

verses.text: You will speak all that I command you, and Aaron your brother will speak to Pharaoh, so that he may let the children of Israel go out of his land.
verses.comment: Moses is the agent, Aaron is the spokesman.

verses.text: But I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and though I multiply my signs and wonders in the land of Egypt,
verses.comment: ‘Harden’ (Heb. ‘qashah’): God strengthens Pharaoh's resolve against letting the Israelites go.

verses.text: Pharaoh will not listen to you. Then I will lay my hand upon Egypt and bring out my people, the children of Israel, from the land of Egypt by great judgments.
verses.comment: ‘Lay my hand’: a phrase for divine intervention.

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the LORD when I stretch out my hand against Egypt and bring out the children of Israel from among them.”
verses.comment: 'I am the LORD': emphatic self-identification by God.

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron did as the LORD commanded them; so they did.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes obedience to God’s command.

verses.text: Now Moses was eighty years old and Aaron eighty-three years old when they spoke to Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Ages included as per original Hebrew.

verses.text: Then the LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying,
verses.comment: Standard intro formula: ‘said to Moses and Aaron’. No significant meaning difference.

verses.text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Prove yourselves by performing a miracle,’ you shall say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh, so it will become a serpent.’”
verses.comment: ‘Serpent’ (Heb. ‘tannin’): can also mean ‘dragon’ or ‘sea monster’, but ‘serpent’ fits context.

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did just as the LORD had commanded. And Aaron threw his staff down before Pharaoh and his servants, and it became a serpent.
verses.comment: Miracle repeated for demonstration before Pharaoh.

verses.text: Then Pharaoh called his wise men and sorcerers, and they also, the magicians of Egypt, did the same by their secret arts.
verses.comment: ‘Secret arts’: Hebrew word suggests occult practices.

verses.text: Each one threw down his staff, and they became serpents. But Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
verses.comment: Aaron's staff swallowing others is a sign of God's superior power.

verses.text: Yet Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, just as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s stubbornness fulfills God’s prediction.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is stubborn; he refuses to let the people go.
verses.comment: ‘Stubborn’ (Heb. ‘kabed’): heavy, unyielding.

verses.text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning, as he is going out to the water. Stand by the riverbank to meet him, and take in your hand the staff that was turned into a serpent.
verses.comment: Meeting by the river refers to the Nile, Egypt's life source.

verses.text: And you shall say to him, ‘The LORD, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to you, saying, “Let my people go, so they may serve me in the wilderness.” But so far you have not listened.’
verses.comment: ‘Serve’—also translated ‘worship’ in various versions.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, “By this you will know that I am the LORD: Behold, I will strike the waters of the Nile with the staff that is in my hand, and they will be turned to blood.”
verses.comment: Waters ‘turned to blood’: historically interpreted as literal, though some scholars debate physical nature.

verses.text: The fish in the Nile will die, and the Nile will stink, and the Egyptians will grow weary of drinking water from the Nile.”
verses.comment: ‘Grow weary’: Hebrew implies strong aversion.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Say to Aaron, ‘Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over their rivers, canals, ponds, and all their pools of water—that they may become blood. And there will be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, both in vessels of wood and in vessels of stone.’”
verses.comment: Water containers also impacted, symbolizing totality of the plague.

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did as the LORD commanded. He lifted up the staff and struck the water in the Nile in the sight of Pharaoh and in the sight of his servants, and all the water in the Nile was turned into blood.
verses.comment: ‘Turned into blood’: direct rendering, aligns with traditional understanding.

verses.text: The fish in the Nile died, and the Nile became foul, so that the Egyptians could not drink water from the Nile. And there was blood throughout all the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the completeness of the disaster.

verses.text: But the magicians of Egypt did the same by their secret arts. So Pharaoh’s heart was hardened, and he did not listen to them, as the LORD had said.
verses.comment: Miraculous imitation further hardens Pharaoh's resolve.

verses.text: Pharaoh turned away, went into his house, and did not set his heart even to this.
verses.comment: ‘Did not set his heart’: Hebrew idiom for ignoring the event.

verses.text: All the Egyptians dug around the Nile for water to drink, because they could not drink any from the river.
verses.comment: Efforts to find potable water around the Nile emphasize severity.

verses.text: Seven days passed after the LORD had struck the Nile.
verses.comment: ‘Seven days’: specific period given before next sign/plague.
